name: smartir-thermal-accelerate-evaporation
author: Charles Xie
description: Blow wind towards water to accelerate its evaporation.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-baking-soda-vinegar
author: Charles Xie
description:
When baking soda is added to vinegar, the temperature drops as a result
of the endothermic reaction.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-beach-at-night
author: Charles Xie
description:
The shallow water zone tends to be cooler than the deep water zone 
and the sandy beach at night.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-beach-at-noon
author: Charles Xie
description:
The shallow water zone tends to be warmer than the deep water zone 
and the beach at noon.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-beach-in-the-morning
author: Charles Xie
description:
The shallow water zone tends to be warmer than the deep water zone 
and the stony wall in the morning.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-bee
author: Charles Xie
description: Bees appear to be warmer when they are working.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-butterfly-sunbath
author: Charles Xie
description: A butterfly takes a sunbath to warm up.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-candle-flame
author: Charles Xie
description:
The flame of a candle appears to be larger in infrared light than
in visible light.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-dynamic-equilibrium
author: Charles Xie
description:
Evaporation and condensation on a piece of paper above a cup of water
reach a dynamic equilibrium. This equilibrium can be disrupted by shifting the paper.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-evaporation-water-vs-alcohol
author: Charles Xie
description: The evaporation of alcohol cools faster than that of water.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-friction-writing
author: Charles Xie
description: Use a chopstick to write numbers that can be seen under a thermal camera.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-full-moon
author: Charles Xie
description: Can we see thermal infrared light from the moon?
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-hand
author: Charles Xie
description:
This video shows the heat transfer from a hand to the surface of a sheet of paper.
After the hand moved away, the temperatures of the contact areas started to decrease.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-head
author: Charles Xie
description:
Breathing in cool air and breathing out warm air 
cause the nostrils to change temperature periodically, which can be used to
measure respiration rate.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-hydrogen-bonds
author: Charles Xie
description:
When a drop of water meets a piece of paper, the formation of hydrogen bonds
between the water molecules and the cellulose molecules causes the temperature to rise. Then
the temperature drops due to water evaporation.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-hydrogen-peroxide-yeast-1
author: Charles Xie
description:
Yeast serves a catalyst to accelerate the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen.
The upper dish shows hydrogen peroxide without yeast for comparison.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-hydrogen-peroxide-yeast-2
author: Charles Xie
description:
Yeast serves a catalyst to accelerate the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen,
an exothermic reaction that releases heat.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-ice-cube-in-water-side-view
display_name: Ice Cube In Water Side View
author: Charles Xie
description:
When an ice tube is dropped into a cup of water, downward currents
develop due to thermal convection.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-ice-cube-in-water-top-view
display_name: Ice Cube In Water Top View
author: Charles Xie
description:
Horizontal swirling currents develop  
at the surface of a cup of water when an ice tube is dropped into it.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-ice-freezing-point-lowering
author: Charles Xie
description:
Adding salt to ice causes it to melt and the temperature to drop significantly. This effect, known
as freezing point lowering, is used to melt ice on roads in the winter.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-impact
author: Charles Xie
description:
When a hard object strikes a ruler, the mechanical energy of impact 
turns into thermal energy at the spot of impact.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-monarch-butterfly
author: Charles Xie
description: A monarch butterfly is warmer than the environment.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-paper-above-alcohol
author: Charles Xie
description:
The comparison between paper above alcohol and paper suggests that 
paper absorbs water but not alcohol.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-paper-ice-cube
author: Charles Xie
description:
When a piece of paper is put on top of a cup of water with a floating
ice cube in it, a part of the paper warms up and another part cools down.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-porch-beams-evening
author: Charles Xie
description:
Compared with the ceiling panels, the beams underlying a porch roof 
record higher temperatures in a summer evening.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-porch-beams-morning
author: Charles Xie
description:
Compared with the ceiling panels, the beams underlying a porch roof 
record lower temperatures in a summer morning.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-propane-tank
author: Charles Xie
description:
The level of liquid propane in a tank can be visualized
using thermal imaging. The tank was in the shade.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-rulers-ice
author: Charles Xie
description:
Heat flows from a metallic ruler
and a wooden ruler to ice cubes show the difference in their thermal conductivities.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-rulers
author: Charles Xie
description:
Heat flows from two thumbs to a metallic ruler
and a wooden ruler show the difference in their thermal conductivities.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-salt-dissolving
author: Charles Xie
description:
When salt (NaCl) dissolves in water, it needs to absorb heat, causing the resulting
solution to cool down to some extent.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-splash1
author: Ji Shen & Charles Xie
description: What do we see through a thermal camera when throwing a stone into water?
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-splash2
author: Ji Shen & Charles Xie
description: What do we see through a thermal camera when throwing a stone into water?
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-splash3
author: Ji Shen & Charles Xie
description: What do we see through a thermal camera when throwing a stone into water?
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-sunflower
author: Charles Xie
description: The disk florets appear to be warmer than the ray florets when the sun is shining on a sunflower.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-sunlight-absorption-gray-colors
author: Charles Xie
description: A darker color absorbs more sunlight energy than a lighter color.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-vapor-pressure-lowering-salt
author: Charles Xie
description:
The existing of salt ions in a solution inhibits evaporation of water, 
causing the effect of evaporative cooling to be weaker than in pure water.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-thermal-waterfowls-grass
author: Charles Xie
description:
The head and feet of a waterfowl appear to be warmer than other parts of its body
covered by feathers.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-waterfowls-pond
author: Charles Xie
description: Waterfowls appear to leave an interesting trace behind when they swim swiftly in water.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-yinyang
author: Charles Xie
description:
Evaporation cools a cup of water. Condensation warms a piece of dry paper 
placed on top of the cup. These opposite effects can be used to create a yin-yang pattern.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-baking-soda-vinegar-comparison
author: Elena Sereiviene
description: When baking soda is added to vinegar, the temperature drops as a result of the endothermic reaction.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-convection-cells-heated-oil
author: Charles Xie
description:
A "cellular" thermal pattern emerges in cooking oil when heated.
This is known as the Benard-Marangoni convection cells.
subject: physics

name: smartir-paper-on-cup
author: Charles Xie
description:
A piece of dry paper was placed on top of a cup of water. 
The paper was then shifted a bit after a minute.
This video shows what happens.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-washing-soda
author: Stephen Sobolewski
description: When washing soda Na2CO3 dissolves in water, it releases heat.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-water-oil-heated
author: Charles Xie
description: The thermal pattern of water on heated oil.
subject: physics

name: smartir-baking-soda-vinegar-concentration
author: Rundong Jiang
description:
In this experiment, four petri dishes contained different concentrations of vinegar 
(0%, 5%, 10%, and 15%). Then the same amount of excessive baking soda was added to them.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-baking-soda-vinegar-temperature
author: Rundong Jiang
description:
In this experiment, three petri dishes contained vinegar at different initial temperatures 
(42°C, 23°C, and 7°C). Then the same amount of excessive baking soda was added to them.
subject: chemistry

name: smartir-natural-convection
author: Rundong Jiang
description:
This experiment uses a hot water jar and a piece of paper to visualize 
natural convection. As the air around the jar warms up, it leaves a 
heat trace on the paper, revealing the convective flow.
subject: physics

name: smartir-thermal-breath-after-exercise
author: Xudong Huang
description:
Breathing in cool air and breathing out warm air 
cause the nostrils to change temperature periodically, which can be used to
measure respiration rate. This experiment shows the rate after exercise.
subject: biology

name: smartir-thermal-breath-before-exercise
author: Xudong Huang
description:
Breathing in cool air and breathing out warm air 
cause the nostrils to change temperature periodically, which can be used to
measure respiration rate. This experiment shows the rate before exercise.
subject: biology
